# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here is one way to implement this function:

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::String)
    question = ""
    answer = ""
    
    lines = split(md, '\n')
    in_question = false
    in_answer = false
    
    for line in lines
        if startswith(line, "# Question")
            in_question = true
            continue
        elseif in_question && !startswith(line, "# Answer")
            question *= ltrim(rstrip(line))
        end
        
        if startswith(line, "# Answer")
            in_answer = true
            continue
        elseif in_answer && !startswith(line, "# Question")
            answer *= ltrim(rstrip(line))
        end
    end
    
    return (question, answer)
end
```
This function works by splitting the input string into lines and iterating over each line. When it finds a line starting with "# Question", it knows to start capturing the question text, and when it finds one starting with "# Answer", it knows to start capturing the answer text. It then concatenates all relevant text to the respective variables `question` or `answer`.

Please note that if you have more than two questions in your markdown file or if a section is not marked as Question or Answer, this code might not work as expected. 

This function assumes that each question and answer section starts with "# Question" or "# Answer", followed by optional spaces/newlines and then the text of the respective section. If there are additional lines before the actual question or answer start, it won't capture them.
